OpenRI User Manual 2023-06-27 Section 1 Overview FIGURE 1.1: The logo for the OpenRI resource. 1.1 Needs Most available interactions are generated or curated between genes (or proteins), and regulatory interactions involving non-coding regions of the genome are less studied, both in terms of resources and utilities. The OpenRI resource addresses these needs, including manual curation of gene-directed regulatory interactions across a wide range of contexts (eg organs, tissues, and cell types), and supporting their use for data mining inclusive of non-coding genome. 1.2 Contents The OpenRI resource is designed to be open and scalable for gene-directed multimodal regulatory interactions. These interactions are currently organised into three modals: Activity-By-Contact (ABC) for enhancer-gene maps, Promoter Capture Hi-C (PCHiC), and Quantitative Trait Loci (QTL). 1.3 Mining In parallel with the growth in summary-level epi/genomic datasets generated from cohort-scale studies, OpenRI provides the users with web-based data-mining opportunities inclusive of non-coding genome, including: Mining - Search, an entry point to mine the resource with the keyword in query returning context-specific pages and gene-specific pages; Mining - Browse, navigating contexts (eg organs, tissues, and cell types) to enable interactive exploration of their regulatory interactions; Mining - RI2Genes, mining the resource to identify potential regulatory genes (see Example Output) from user-input data; Mining - RI2Terms, mining the resource to identify potential regulatory genes and enriched ontology terms (see Example Output) from user-input data.

Section 2 Web-server 2.1 Frontpage FIGURE 2.1: The landing frontpage of the OpenRI web-server, featuring 4 key data-mining opportunities: Search, Browse, RI2Genes, and RI2Terms. 2.2 Mobile The OpenRI web-server is developed to be mobile-first and responsive (frontend), while a next-generation Perl web framework backend enables real-time browsing and mining of the OpenRI resource. FIGURE 2.2: The screenshots for the OpenRI web-server visited using a smartphone. Left: the frontpage; Right: the about page.

Section 3 Mining - Search The faceted search is a mining hub, providing hyperlinks from the search results. Full text query is supported for contexts and genes. Search results for contexts are hyperlinked to context-specific pages, displaying the context information as well as the tabular display for regulatory interactions between genomic regions and genes. Search results for a particular gene are hyperlinked to the gene-specific page, displaying the gene information, its regulatory interactions (displayed separately for different modals), and where available, its annotated terms (of different ontologies). FIGURE 3.1: Faceted search enables centralised data-mining opportunities of the OpenRI resource.

Section 5 Mining - RI2Genes 5.1 Input Interface 5.2 Interactive Results

Section 5 Mining - RI2Genes 5.1 Input Interface Input Step 1 and Step 2: Enter a list of user-input genomic regions, and specify the reference genome build. Please make sure that the input genomic coordinates (Step 1) are consistent with the specified genome build (Step 2). Step 3: Select from a list of contexts under different modals (PCHiC, ABC, and QTL). Output Example Output includes interactive tables for regulatory genes and evidence. A summary of input data and the runtime (computed on the server side) is also returned to the users. FIGURE 5.1: The RI2Genes interface. 5.2 Interactive Results Under the tab Input Information, Interactive table lists user-input genomic regions. FIGURE 5.2: A summary table of the user-input data under the tab Input Information returned for the exploration. Under the tab Output: Regulatory Genes, Regulatory Gene table lists regulatory genes that are also hyperlinked to gene-specific information page, while Evidence table displays information about how to define regulatory genes, that is, using which contexts and which regulatory interactions. FIGURE 5.3: Regulatory Gene table listing regulatory genes under the tab Output: Regulatory Genes.
Section 6 Mining - RI2Terms 6.1 Input Interface 6.2 Interactive Results

Section 6 Mining - RI2Terms 6.1 Input Interface Input Step 1 and Step 2: Enter a list of user-input genomic regions, and specify the reference genome build. Please make sure that the input genomic coordinates (Step 1) are consistent with the specified genome build (Step 2). Step 3: Select from a list of contexts under different modals (PCHiC, ABC, and QTL). Step 4: Specify the top regulatory genes and select from a list of ontologies to identify enriched ontology terms. Output Example Output includes interactive tables for regulatory genes (and evidence) and ontology terms, as well as graphical plots for enriched terms. A summary of input data and the runtime (computed on the server side) is also returned to the users. FIGURE 6.1: The RI2Terms interface. 6.2 Interactive Results Under the tab Input Information, Interactive table lists user-input genomic regions. Under the tab Output: Regulatory Genes, Regulatory Gene table lists regulatory genes that are also hyperlinked to gene-specific information page, while Evidence table displays information about how to define regulatory genes, that is, using which contexts and which regulatory interactions. Under the tab Output: Ontology Terms, Ontology Term table displays enriched ontology terms. FIGURE 6.2: Ontology Term table lists enriched ontology terms under the tab Output: Ontology Terms. Under the tab Output: Plots, two output plots Dotplot and Forest plot illustrate enriched ontology terms. Also provided are the downloadable PDF files.
